An Iranian-American filmmaker who'd been detained in Iraq for nearly two months has been released.
Cyrus Kar was working on a documentary when Iraqi forces found suspicious materials in the trunk of a taxicab he'd hired.

NPR's Lourdes Garcia-Navarro joins me on the line from Baghdad.
Hi, Lourdes.
Hi.
What do we know about Cyrus Kar?
Well, Cyrus Kar is a 44-year-old, Iranian-born, American citizen who came to the US when he was very young.
He served in the Navy, and he worked in the computer industry.
His family describe him as a patriot who supported the war in Iraq.

In the past few years he became interested in film, and he'd been working on a documentary about his namesake, Cyrus the Great, a Persian king who lived about 500 years before Christ and who's believed to have written the first-ever human rights charter.
He's filmed in Iran and Turkey and Afghanistan.

The story brings us to Iraq because he then came to Baghdad to finish some of the final sequences, mainly in and around the ancient city of Babylon, which is one of the places that Cyrus the Great conquered.
So then how did he come to be in US custody?
Well, it's a very odd story.
On May 17th, he left his Baghdad hotel, from what we know, with his Iranian cameraman in a taxi.
Now they went north, and near the town of Balad he was stopped by the Iraqi army at a checkpoint.
They discovered in the back of the taxicab several dozen washing machine timers.
Now these are frequently used here in roadside bombs, so that raised the alarm.
He was then handed over to the US military, where he was accused of being an enemy combatant, but no charges were ever filed.
Kar's relatives say that FBI agents searched his home in Los Angeles, but they later told them that he'd passed a polygraph test and he'd been cleared of any charges.
Cleared but not released.

He was cleared of charges somewhere in the middle of his detention, but they really did not release him, which is one of the reasons why his family then this week decided to, with the help of the American Civil Liberties Union, launch a suit against the US government.
They contend that he was held even after the FBI told them that he'd been cleared.
And so is there an official reason for why, after these nearly two months, he's been released?
Well, the official reason given is that basically he was cleared of all the charges and his story checked out.
Apparently, the FBI agents told the family that the washing machine timers, it had been determined, belonged to the taxi driver, who was transporting them to a friend.
That taxi driver is still in American custody.

But Kar and his Iranian cameraman have been released because, quite frankly, it was determined that they had nothing to do with the transportation of the timers; they just happened to get into the wrong cab.
